description: Europe Square is the historic heart of Batumi's Old Town, originally built in the late 19th century during the Ottoman Empire. Formerly known as Era Square, it was renamed in 1997 when the Adjara Autonomous Republic joined the Assembly of European Regions, symbolizing Georgia's European aspirations and centuries-old ties to European civilization. The square was restored and reconstructed in the early 2000s, transforming it into a vibrant cultural hub that blends historical architecture with modern elements.
highlights: Medea Statue - The iconic bronze statue by sculptor Davit Khmaladze (2007) depicting the Colchis princess Medea holding the Golden Fleece, standing on a massive pedestal as the square's centerpiece and symbol of ancient Colchis glory

Astronomical Clock Tower - A remarkable clock created in Germany in 2010, mounted on the former National Bank building facade, displaying time, cosmological data, sun and moon positions, moon phases, and sunrise/sunset times

19th-20th Century Architectural Ensemble - Surrounding buildings showcase a harmonious blend of traditional Georgian, European, and Eastern-influenced architectural styles with preserved decorative elements and ornaments from Batumi's prosperous 19th century
Central Fountain - A large fountain perfect for cooling off during hot summer days and adding to the square's pleasant atmosphere
Memed Abashidze Avenue Location - Situated in the central part of Old Town, making it easily accessible and a natural gathering point
tips: Free entry - no admission fees to explore the square
Best visited between April to June or September to October for pleasant weather and fewer crowds
Located just 10 minutes walk from Batumi Boulevard - follow any perpendicular street toward the city center
Only 5 minutes walking distance from Batumi Piazza
Visit during festivals - the square hosts annual events including Gandagana folk festival, Batumoba festival, Christmas market, and international concerts
Explore surrounding cafes and restaurants offering local cuisine with beautiful views of the square
Particularly vibrant during New Year's celebrations when large crowds gather
Take time to appreciate the architectural details on building facades - they tell stories of Batumi's multiethnic history
Best photography opportunities early morning or evening when lighting highlights the Medea statue and architectural features
vibe: Historic yet lively, Europe Square exudes a sophisticated European atmosphere while celebrating Georgian heritage. The square seamlessly blends old-world charm with modern vitality, serving as both a cultural landmark and social gathering space. The presence of the majestic Medea statue creates a sense of mythological grandeur, while the surrounding 19th-century architecture transports visitors to Batumi's golden age. Throughout the day, the square buzzes with locals and tourists enjoying cafes, admiring the fountain, and photographing the unique astronomical clock. During festivals and concerts, it transforms into an energetic celebration hub, yet maintains an elegant, refined character that reflects Batumi's aspirations as a cosmopolitan Black Sea destination with deep European connections.
